headline.main: For Those Who Would Eat No Fat

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Donald Small devised his recipe for turning out red meat low in fat and cholesterol, he was thinking not of high science, but of his palate. "I had a cholesterol problem, and had tried a very low-fat diet with almost no meat, but I love food and found it very difficult," said Dr. Small, a professor of medicine and biophysics at the Boston University Medical School as well as an amateur chef. "I thought I'd better devise a way to cook meat so that it met American Heart Assoication guidelines."

headline.main: Sugar Group's Effort Draws Health Organization's Fire

docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT to spoon some sugar on your breakfast cornflakes? Go right ahead, whatever your New Year's resolution. Or at least that's what the Sugar Association, the trade group that represents makers and marketers of sugar, is urging consumers to do in a new print campaign that begins later this month. But in an indication of the continuing controversy surrounding sugar, a health advocacy organization has criticized parts of the new effort as deceptive, a charge denied by the Sugar Association, which is based in Washington.
